cbc_differential.name: CBC and Differential
cbc_differential.description: Complete Blood Count with differential white blood cell count

wbc.name: White Blood Cells
wbc.explanation: White blood cells help fight infections. Low levels may indicate immune system problems, while high levels may suggest infection or inflammation.

rbc.name: Red Blood Cells
rbc.explanation: Red blood cells carry oxygen throughout your body. Low levels may indicate anemia, while high levels may suggest dehydration or lung disease.

hemoglobin.name: Hemoglobin
hemoglobin.explanation: Hemoglobin is the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen. Low levels indicate anemia, which can cause fatigue and weakness.

hematocrit.name: Hematocrit
hematocrit.explanation: Hematocrit measures the fraction of blood volume made up of red blood cells. It helps diagnose anemia and polycythemia. Normal range for adults is 0.40-0.52 L/L.

platelets.name: Platelets
platelets.explanation: Platelets help your blood clot. Low levels increase bleeding risk, while high levels may increase clotting risk.

neutrophils.name: Neutrophils
neutrophils.explanation: Neutrophils are the most common type of white blood cell and fight bacterial infections. High levels often indicate bacterial infection.

lymphocytes.name: Lymphocytes
lymphocytes.explanation: Lymphocytes fight viral infections and include T-cells and B-cells. High levels may indicate viral infection or certain blood cancers.

vitamin_b12.name: Vitamin B12
vitamin_b12.description: Essential vitamin for nerve function and red blood cell formation

b12.name: Vitamin B12
b12.explanation: Vitamin B12 is essential for nerve function and making red blood cells. Low levels can cause anemia, fatigue, and neurological problems.

iron_panel.name: Iron Studies
iron_panel.description: Tests to assess iron status and metabolism

iron.name: Serum Iron
iron.explanation: Measures the amount of iron in your blood. Low levels may indicate iron deficiency, while high levels may suggest iron overload.

tibc.name: Total Iron Binding Capacity
tibc.explanation: Measures your blood's capacity to bind iron. High levels often indicate iron deficiency.

iron_saturation.name: Iron Saturation Index
iron_saturation.explanation: Shows what percentage of your iron-binding capacity is being used. Low levels suggest iron deficiency.

ferritin.name: Ferritin
ferritin.explanation: Ferritin stores iron in your body. Low levels indicate iron deficiency, while high levels may suggest inflammation or iron overload.

urinalysis.name: Urinalysis
urinalysis.description: Comprehensive urine analysis for kidney function and overall health

color.name: Urine Color
color.explanation: Normal urine should be yellow to straw-colored. Dark urine may indicate dehydration, while very pale urine may suggest overhydration.

clarity.name: Urine Clarity
clarity.explanation: Normal urine should be clear. Cloudy urine may indicate infection, kidney stones, or other urinary tract problems.

ph.name: Urine pH
ph.explanation: Measures how acidic or basic your urine is. Abnormal pH may indicate kidney problems, urinary tract infections, or metabolic disorders.

glucose.name: Urine Glucose
glucose.explanation: Glucose in urine may indicate diabetes or kidney problems. Normal urine should not contain detectable glucose.

protein.name: Urine Protein
protein.explanation: Protein in urine may indicate kidney damage or disease. Small amounts may be normal after exercise.

nitrites.name: Nitrites
nitrites.explanation: Positive nitrites often indicate bacterial urinary tract infection, particularly from gram-negative bacteria.

leukocytes.name: Leukocyte Esterase
leukocytes.explanation: Positive leukocyte esterase indicates white blood cells in urine, often suggesting urinary tract infection or inflammation.

ketones.name: Ketones
ketones.explanation: Ketones in urine may indicate diabetic ketoacidosis, starvation, or low-carbohydrate diets.

lipid_panel.name: Lipid Panel
lipid_panel.description: Tests to assess cardiovascular disease risk

total_cholesterol.name: Total Cholesterol
total_cholesterol.explanation: Total cholesterol measures all cholesterol in your blood. High levels increase risk of heart disease and stroke.

hdl.name: HDL Cholesterol
hdl.explanation: HDL is 'good' cholesterol that helps remove other cholesterol from arteries. Higher levels are better for heart health.

ldl.name: LDL Cholesterol
ldl.explanation: LDL is 'bad' cholesterol that can build up in arteries. Lower levels reduce risk of heart disease and stroke.

triglycerides.name: Triglycerides
triglycerides.explanation: Triglycerides are a type of fat in blood. High levels increase risk of heart disease and may indicate metabolic syndrome.

liver_function.name: Liver Function Tests
liver_function.description: Tests to assess liver health and function

alt.name: ALT (Alanine Aminotransferase)
alt.explanation: ALT is an enzyme mainly found in the liver. High levels may indicate liver damage or disease.

bilirubin_total.name: Total Bilirubin
bilirubin_total.explanation: Bilirubin is a waste product from breaking down red blood cells. High levels may indicate liver problems or blood disorders.

ggt.name: GGT (Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase)
ggt.explanation: GGT is an enzyme found in liver and bile ducts. High levels may indicate liver disease or bile duct problems.

thyroid_function.name: Thyroid Function Tests
thyroid_function.description: Tests to assess thyroid gland function

tsh.name: TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone)
tsh.explanation: TSH controls thyroid hormone production. High levels may indicate underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism), while low levels may indicate overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism).

free_t4.name: Free T4 (Thyroxine)
free_t4.explanation: Free T4 is the active form of thyroid hormone. Low levels may indicate hypothyroidism, while high levels may indicate hyperthyroidism.

electrolytes_renal.name: Electrolytes and Renal Function
electrolytes_renal.description: Tests for kidney function and electrolyte balance

sodium.name: Sodium
sodium.explanation: Sodium helps regulate fluid balance and blood pressure. Abnormal levels may indicate kidney problems, dehydration, or heart failure.

potassium.name: Potassium
potassium.explanation: Potassium is essential for heart and muscle function. Abnormal levels can cause dangerous heart rhythm problems.

creatinine.name: Creatinine
creatinine.explanation: Creatinine is a waste product filtered by kidneys. High levels may indicate kidney disease or reduced kidney function.

egfr.name: eGFR (Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate)
egfr.explanation: eGFR estimates how well your kidneys filter waste. Values below 60 may indicate chronic kidney disease.

urate.name: Uric Acid (Urate)
urate.explanation: Uric acid is a waste product. High levels may cause gout or indicate kidney problems.

diabetes.name: Diabetes Monitoring
diabetes.description: Tests for diabetes diagnosis and monitoring

hba1c.name: Hemoglobin A1c
hba1c.explanation: HbA1c shows average blood sugar over 2-3 months. Values 6.5% or higher indicate diabetes, while 6.1-6.4% indicate prediabetes.

normal.label: Normal
normal.description: Result is within normal reference range

borderline.label: Borderline
borderline.description: Result is slightly outside normal range but not significantly abnormal

abnormal.label: Abnormal
abnormal.description: Result is significantly outside normal reference range
